title: E field of distribution - switching signs of rings

content.question: Two charged rings are concentric and have radii <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and <math alttext="2 uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math>, as shown in the figure. Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> is located on a line that passes through the common center of the rings and is perpendicular to the plane of the rings. Each ring is uniformly charged, initially with charges <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="negative uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> on the ring of radius <math alttext="2 uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math> and the ring of radius <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, respectively. If each ring is given the opposite charge from what it had initially, what happens to the electric field magnitude <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math> at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>? What evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math> stays the same. The integrals that express the electric field contributions of the rings change in sign but not magnitude.
<math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math> stays the same. The net charge of the two-ring system does not change.

<math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math> changes. The contribution to the electric field at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math> from the larger ring is greater in magnitude than the contribution from the smaller ring.
